explanation: Based on the LCA methodology, the 250 kg CO2e figure provided already aggregates major energy‐intensive steps including raw material extraction/processing (such as aluminum smelting), machining, and final precision assembly. In line with the GHG Protocol Product Standard and ISO 14040/14044 methods, additional stages (transportation/distribution and end‐of‐life disposal) are typically estimated to add roughly 10% to the cradle‐to‐gate emissions. Applying an approximate increment of 25 kg CO2e (10% of 250 kg) yields a total life cycle footprint of about 275 kg CO2e per finished unit. This approach is consistent with assumptions under PAS 2050 and ISO/TS 14067 using both primary and secondary data to reflect the complete product life cycle.

The calculation follows a cradle‐to‐grave approach. The provided manufacturing estimate (220 kg CO2e) reflects Scope 1 & 2 emissions from high‐tech production (energy‐intensive aluminum refining, machining, electronics fabrication, etc.) as explained. In addition, using standard LCA methods (ISO 14040/14044) and under the GHG Protocol and PAS 2050, we estimate that upstream processes (material extraction and processing) as well as transportation/distribution and end‐of‐life disposal (all Scope 3) add roughly 25% (~55 kg CO2e) to the product’s footprint. Thus, the total carbon footprint is roughly 275.00 kg CO2e.

Assuming the finished MacBook Pro weighs roughly 1.6 kg, the manufacturing stage emits about 150 kg CO2e per kilogram of product (1.6 kg × 150 kg CO2e/kg = 240 kg CO2e). In a simplified cradle‐to‐grave approach—as recommended by the GHG Protocol Product Standard and following ISO 14040/14044, PAS 2050, and ISO/TS 14067—we also include emissions from material extraction and processing (estimated at ~30% of the manufacturing emissions), transportation/distribution (~10%), and end‐of‐life disposal (~5%). These additional stages contribute roughly 72 kg, 24 kg, and 12 kg CO2e, respectively. Summing these (240 + 72 + 24 + 12) gives an overall carbon footprint of approximately 348 kg CO2e. This “back‐of‐the‐envelope” calculation uses average emission factors and percentage assumptions common in LCA studies for electronics.
